repnme.cdata!:
Chile - Santiago Urban Transport
            Programmatic Development Policy Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Santiago Urban Transport
            Programmatic Development Policy Loan Project for Chile were
            as follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk
            to development outcome was moderate, the Bank performance
            was moderately satisfactory, and the Borrower performance
            was also moderately satisfactory.  Some lessons learned
            included: lack of a holistic approach may result in
            emphasizing one concern over another, for example, focusing
            mainly on environmental and economic considerations may lead
            to a design with unnecessarily fewer and larger buses.
            However, fewer and larger buses reduce comfort and increase
            waiting times. Such a decrease in service quality is a
            disincentive for public transport use and will, at least in
            the long run, go against environmental and economic
            considerations. Hence, it is important that a design that
            includes user participation finds the right balance between
            environmental and economic considerations and service
            quality. Travel and network models are excellent tools to
            evaluate network designs, but over reliance on normative
            analytical tools that 'optimize' a network subject
            to a set of assumptions, especially in areas that assume
            behavioral changes, should be avoided. The modeling exercise
            also needs to include 'bottom up' inputs, such as
            information on the importance in terms of overall weight
            people give to transfers, waiting, and walking. The Santiago
            experience showed that it is not advisable to redesign the
            public transport network without considering the existing
            information on travel demand and destination available
            through the operators. Additionally, stakeholders'
            involvement in the network design process, especially the
            municipalities comprising the metropolitan area, operators
            and users, is essential, and the design concept for the
            network needs to be extensively modeled before implementation.

6386874.majtheme: Social dev/gender/inclusion,Environment and natural resource management,Urban development,Human development

repnme.cdata!:
Chile - Santiago Urban Transport
            Programmatic Development Policy Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The main development objectives of the
            Santiago Urban Transport Programmatic Development Policy
            Loan will be to contribute to its transformation into a
            highly competitive, world city, and improve its quality of
            life, by upgrading the level of transport services for
            residents (particularly low income residents), and
            businesses, reduce resource costs, and increase
            environmental quality. The specific objectives are to: a)
            Reduce transport costs in their financial, travel time, and
            environmental dimensions, and increase transport efficiency;
            b) Improve the coordination of public sector activities in
            land use, transport planning, infrastructure investment,
            traffic management, and bus franchising; c) Address urban
            poverty by improving access to jobs, and economic
            opportunities; and, d) Enhance social inclusion, through
            improved access to schools, health facilities, and wider
            social interaction. Although the risks of this program are
            deemed modest, due to Chile's excellent track record in
            economic management, program implementation, and
            transparency, some issues nevertheless, deserve attention.
            These include: some users may sustain increases in waiting
            and access times, which offset the benefits they obtain in
            improved trunk travel times; existing transit workers, and
            operators may resist a change in the status quo, and the
            proposed public transport reforms; and, a change in
            government administration due to the next presidential
            elections, could lower the government's level of
            commitment to the reform.

repnme.cdata!:
Chile - Santiago Urban Transport Deferred
            Drawdown Sector Adjustment Loan Project and Santiago Urban
            Transport Sector Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Chile Santiago Urban Transport
            Deferred Drawdown Sector Adjustment Loan Project and
            Santiago Urban Transport Sector Adjustment Loan Project
            constitute an adjustment operation comprising a
            single-tranche Sector Adjustment Loan (SECAL) with a DDO
            feature (Deferred Drawdown Option Loan) and a two-tranche
            Sector Adjustment Loan (SECAL). The loans support an ongoing
            and broad program of reforms in the urban transport sector
            in the Metropolitan Area of Santiago. The loans are
            supported by a companion technical assistance loan (Report
            No: 28521-CL) to help facilitate the achievement of reforms
            targeted for second tranche release and to provide technical
            follow-up, monitoring, and strengthening of the
            implementation of the Santiago Urban Transport Reform. The
            main development objectives of the SECALS are to improve the
            level of transport services to the residents (particularly
            low income residents) and businesses, reduce resource costs,
            and increase environmental quality. The specific objectives
            (i) Reduce transport costs in their financial, travel time,
            and environmental dimensions, and increase transport
            efficiency; (ii) Improve the coordination o f public sector
            activities in land use, transport planning, infrastructure
            investment, traffic management, and bus franchising; (iii)
            address urban poverty through improving access to jobs and
            economic opportunities; and (iv) enhance social inclusion
            through improved access to schools, health facilities, and
            wider social interaction. Benefits include (i) efficiency
            improvements that contribute to the city economy and hence
            economic growth; (ii) resource savings from transferring the
            bus flows in major corridors to an exclusive space, the
            reduction of bus vehicle-km on the street system, the
            rationalization of the route network, and the reduction of
            revenue risks from operators; (iii) environmental
            improvements (higher air quality and lower noise); (iv)
            increased quality of service for passengers who live in the
            catchment areas of the metro extensions and the new metro
            line; (v) increased comfort, safety and reliability for bus
            passengers; (vi) comprehensive coverage of bus feeder routes
            particularly in poor neighborhoods;  (vii) savings stemming
            from the implementation of a unified fare system; and (viii)
            reduced use of 'road space' by car drivers
            contributing to a reduction in congestion. The risks of this
            program are deemed modest. Chile's excellent track
            record in economic management, program implementation and
            transparency make the satisfactory completion of the program
            highly likely. Nevertheless, some issues deserving special
            attention include: increases in waiting and access times;
            resistance from existing transit workers and operators
            opposed to a change in the status quo; unsuccessful
            concession tenders for bus services; potential vulnerability
            to negative external events including less favorable
            commodity prices, higher international interest rates,
            adverse regional developments, as well as domestic factors
            such as contingent fiscal liabilities, external indebtedness
            of the corporate sector, and energy supply risks.

repnme.cdata!:
Chile - Santiago Urban Transport Project :
            environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Santiago Urban Transport Project
            will improve the services to residents, and reduce resource
            costs through improved competitive mechanisms in public
            transport services, re-allocating general traffic, within a
            planned metropolitan transport framework. This environmental
            assessment (EA) looks first at the physical characteristics
            (climate, topography, ecology and hydrology) to assess and
            provide mitigation measures as follows. To prevent soil
            erosion, appropriate drainage systems should be in place,
            including maintenance measures to avoid surface, and
            groundwater contamination. Likewise, soil stabilization
            measures, and re-vegetation (native plants protective
            barriers) should further prevent erosion, and landslides.
            Regular spraying on construction surfaces, and materials
            would minimize air pollution, while vehicles and equipment
            should be regularly inspected to avoid contamination due to
            lubricant, and oil spills. Noise abatement measures shall
            include protective barriers, daytime working schedules, and
            traffic speeding. Water supply and sewage treatment plants
            should be adequately controlled, through regular inspections
            to prevent toxic, and chemical substances reaching the water
            supply flows. Following construction, vegetative propagation
            should be practiced, particularly on slopes, and plants
            protective barriers. Diversion of river flows should be
            avoided as possible, to reduce adverse water levels, and contamination.
